{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Theorem.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" Among all positive integers, the integer 1 is the largest.      "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"tableRow","content":[{"type":"tableCell","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Step 2."}]},{"type":"tableCell","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Since "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" n^2 > n "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", it is not the largest positive integer."}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"tableRow","content":[{"type":"tableCell","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Step 3."}]},{"type":"tableCell","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Therefore, 1 is the largest integer."}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The proof "works" by eliminating all possibilities for the largest positive integer other than "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" n = 1 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", and then claiming that this remaining choice must hence be the largest positive integer. "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
However, what is has shown is just that "If there is a largest positive integer, then the only possibility for it (according to this proof) is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" n = 1 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"". As such, because there isn't a "largest positive integer", hence the result of "it is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" n = 1 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"" does not follow."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"horizontalRule"},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Sherlock's quote applies to the context of his private investigation cases, where he knows that the scenario has existed and is thus looking for a reason to explain its existence. If so, by eliminating all but one possibility, we know that whatever remains must be the truth. It assumes existence through the real-world context that is implicit in his quote. A common scenario that happens is for people to assume that Brilliant problems are well-phrased, and thus there is a correct answer, so they can proceed by elimination."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"In truth, this misconception of "If I'm left with 1 answer, then that is correct" occurs especially in geometry problems.  The OP takes the algebraic interpretation, sets up the algebraic equation and solves for a certain value. However, it is possible for the answer to result in a physically impossible scenario. E.g. requires negative length which isn't accounted for, makes a certain angle reflex and so the wrong value is used, etc. This is why I often stress "Can this be achieved?" when reviewing a solution for mathematical rigor. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Here","marks":[{"attrs":{"href":"","target":"_blank"},"type":"link"}]},{"type":"text","text":" is an example where the solution assumes that there is a unique answer, and so merely calculates a necessary condition that gives a unique potential answer. For completeness, it has to show that this potential answer indeed satisfies the given initial conditions."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}
